skill.name: datamol
skill.description: Pythonic wrapper around RDKit with simplified interface and sensible defaults. Preferred for standard drug discovery: SMILES parsing, standardization, descriptors, fingerprints, clustering, 3D conformers, parallel processing. Returns native rdkit.Chem.Mol objects. For advanced control or custom parameters, use rdkit directly.

skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill with no executable scripts or hidden logic. Examples include local and remote file I/O through datamol, which introduces minimal capability risk.

content.value_statement: Cheminformatics tasks are slow when RDKit APIs are complex. This skill provides concise patterns for common molecular parsing, descriptors, and file workflows.
actual_capabilities: Convert SMILES to RDKit molecules with dm.to_mol and filter invalid entries
Standardize molecules or SMILES with dm.standardize_mol and dm.standardize_smiles
Read SDF, SMILES, CSV, and Excel datasets into dataframes
Write SDF, SMILES, and Excel outputs from molecules or dataframes
Generate molecular fingerprints with dm.to_fp for similarity workflows
limitations: Requires datamol and RDKit installed in the runtime environment
Parsing failures return None and require user-side filtering
Butina clustering scales poorly for very large libraries
Remote file access needs correct fsspec backends and credentials

use_cases.title: Standardize libraries
use_cases.description: Clean and normalize SMILES before descriptor or fingerprint analysis.

use_cases.title: Build molecular features
use_cases.description: Generate descriptor tables or fingerprints for model training data.

use_cases.title: Convert file formats
use_cases.description: Move between SDF, SMILES, and CSV with consistent molecule columns.

prompt_templates.title: Parse SMILES list
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert this SMILES list to molecules, drop invalid entries, and return canonical SMILES.

prompt_templates.title: Standardize dataset
prompt_templates.prompt: Standardize these SMILES with metal disconnection and reionization, then report how many remain valid.

prompt_templates.title: Batch descriptors
prompt_templates.prompt: Compute standard descriptors for this molecule list with parallel jobs and summarize the top five by molecular weight.

prompt_templates.title: Fingerprint similarity
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate ECFP fingerprints for these molecules and group them into similarity clusters using a Tanimoto cutoff of 0.2.

output_examples.input: Standardize these SMILES and compute basic descriptors
output: Parsed 120 SMILES and kept 115 valid molecules
Standardized molecules with metal disconnection and reionization
Computed MW, LogP, HBD, HBA, and TPSA for each molecule

best_practices: Standardize molecules before descriptor or fingerprint generation
Filter None molecules after parsing to avoid downstream errors
Use parallel jobs for large descriptor batches
anti_patterns: Run Butina clustering on very large libraries without sampling
Treat example defaults as optimal for all projects

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. The guidance is platform neutral and works with those assistants.

faq.question: What are the scale limits for clustering?
faq.answer: Butina clustering is best for smaller sets due to full distance matrix cost.

faq.question: Can it integrate with cloud storage?
faq.answer: Yes, via fsspec paths such as S3 or HTTP if the backends are installed.

faq.question: Does it access sensitive data?
faq.answer: No. The skill is documentation only and does not access credentials by itself.

faq.question: What if SMILES parsing fails?
faq.answer: Filter None results and consider standardize_smiles or fix_mol.

faq.question: How does it compare to using RDKit directly?
faq.answer: It provides simpler defaults while returning native RDKit molecule objects.
